metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. One of the tick marks is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look at where the highlighted [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] falls on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the number line with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into equal parts. [event:A_compare] Notice how the highlighted tick mark divides the line into two equal sections. [event:A_compare_shaded] The shaded section shows one out of two parts.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. [event:A_arrow] We start at 0 and count to the highlighted tick mark. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is split into 2 equal parts, and the highlighted mark is at the first part. That means we've gone 1 out of 2 parts, which is one-half. See how the tick mark sits exactly halfway between 0 and 1?

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. The [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] at the halfway point is one-half.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. One of the tick marks is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many equal parts from zero to the highlighted tick.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the number line with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into equal parts. [event:A_compare] Each part represents one third. [event:A_compare_shaded] Count how many thirds it takes to reach the highlighted [vocab]tick mark[/vocab].

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on a number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into 3 equal parts, so each part is one third. [event:A_arrow] Starting from zero, we count one third, then two thirds to reach the highlighted tick mark. That's why the answer is [fraction numerator=2 denominator=3]two thirds[/fraction].

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The highlighted [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is at two-thirds.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. One of the tick marks is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the tick marks from zero to the highlighted mark.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal intervals

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts showing the position of the highlighted tick

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] The number line is divided into 4 equal parts between 0 and 1. [event:A_compare_shaded] Count how many parts you move from zero to reach the highlighted tick.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into fourths - that's 4 equal parts. [event:A_arrow] Starting from zero, we count one, two, three parts to reach the highlighted tick. That means we're at three-fourths, or [fraction numerator=3 denominator=4]three fourths[/fraction]. The bottom number tells us how many equal parts total, and the top number tells us how many parts we counted from zero.

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The highlighted tick is at three-fourths.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. There's a purple [vocab]tick mark[/vocab]. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the purple tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the intervals from zero to the purple tick.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the number line with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into 6 equal parts. [event:A_compare] Each interval represents one-sixth. [event:A_compare_shaded] Count how many intervals from zero to the purple tick.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on a number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] goes from 0 to 1 and is divided into 6 [vocab]equal intervals[/vocab]. [event:A_arrow] Starting at zero, we count each interval: one-sixth, two-sixths, three-sixths, four-sixths, five-sixths. The purple tick is at the fifth interval, so it represents five-sixths. That's how we identify [vocab]fractions[/vocab] on a number line.

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The purple tick is at five-sixths.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. One [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is highlighted. Which fraction matches that [vocab]position[/vocab]?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the intervals from zero to the highlighted tick.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal intervals

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts highlighting the position of the tick mark

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] The number line is divided into 8 equal parts. [event:A_compare_shaded] Count how many intervals from zero to reach the highlighted tick.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: [event:A_arrow] Let me show you how to find this. We start at zero and count each [vocab]interval[/vocab] to the highlighted tick: one, two, three, four, five, six, seven. That's 7 intervals out of 8 total, which gives us seven-eighths. See how counting from zero helps us identify the [vocab]fraction[/vocab]?

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The highlighted tick is at seven-eighths.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. One of the tick marks is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches this tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many equal parts are between 0 and 1.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the number line with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] The number line is divided into 3 equal parts. [event:A_compare_shaded] The highlighted [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is at the first division.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. [event:A_arrow] Starting from 0, we make one jump to reach the highlighted tick mark. The whole distance from 0 to 1 is divided into 3 equal parts, so one jump is one-third. That's why the highlighted tick mark represents [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction].

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The highlighted [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is at one-third.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. One of the tick marks is highlighted. Which fraction matches that [vocab]position[/vocab]?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many jumps from zero to the highlighted tick.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the first or the top shape with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the first or the top shape with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] Notice how the number line is divided into equal parts. [event:A_compare_shaded] The highlighted tick is the first mark after zero.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on a number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. [event:A_arrow] We count from zero to the highlighted tick - that's one jump out of four equal parts total. That makes it one-fourth, or [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. See how the first tick represents the first fourth?

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. The first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] represents one-fourth.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab] divided into sixths. One [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the tick marks from zero to the highlighted one.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal intervals

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts highlighting the intervals up to the marked tick

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into sixths, so each interval represents one-sixth. [event:A_compare][event:A_compare_shaded] Count how many intervals from zero to the highlighted [vocab]tick mark[/vocab].

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into six equal parts, so we're working with sixths. [event:A_arrow] Starting from zero, we count each tick mark: one-sixth, two-sixths, three-sixths, four-sixths. The highlighted tick is at the fourth position, so it represents four-sixths or [fraction numerator=4 denominator=6]four sixths[/fraction]. That's how we count positions on a number line to identify [vocab]fractions[/vocab].

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The highlighted tick is at four-sixths.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab] divided into eighths. One [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the tick marks from zero to the highlighted one.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal intervals

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts showing the highlighted tick position

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into eighths, so each interval represents one-eighth. [event:A_compare][event:A_compare_shaded] Count how many intervals from zero to the highlighted tick.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. We start at zero and count each [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] as we move right. [event:A_arrow] The arrow shows us counting from zero to the highlighted tick - that's 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 intervals. Since the number line is divided into eighths, the highlighted tick represents six-eighths, or [fraction numerator=6 denominator=8]six eighths[/fraction]. That's how we identify the fraction on a number line.

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The highlighted tick is at six-eighths.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. There's a [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] highlighted in purple. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches this tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many intervals from zero to the purple tick.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal intervals

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts showing the position of the purple tick

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into 4 equal parts. [event:A_compare] Look at how many intervals you need to count from zero to reach the purple tick. [event:A_compare_shaded] The purple tick is at the second interval.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on the number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. The [vocab]number line[/vocab] is divided into 4 [vocab]equal intervals[/vocab], so we're working with fourths. [event:A_arrow] Starting from zero, we count to the purple tick: one-fourth, two-fourths. The purple tick is at two-fourths. That's how we identify the [vocab]fraction[/vocab] on a number line.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. The highlighted tick is at two-fourths.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. One [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches the highlighted tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many equal parts are between 0 and 1.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the first or the top shape with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the first or the top shape with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] The number line is divided into 6 equal parts. [event:A_compare_shaded] The highlighted tick is the first mark after zero.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on a number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. [event:A_arrow] When we count from zero to the highlighted tick, we move one-sixth of the way along the number line. The number line has 6 equal parts between 0 and 1, and the highlighted tick is at the first position. That's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction].

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] after zero represents one-sixth.

metadata.goal_text: The student can label a given tick mark on the number line with fraction notation.

steps.dialogue: Look at this [vocab]number line[/vocab]. One [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is highlighted. What [vocab]fraction[/vocab] does it represent?

prompt.text: Select the fraction that matches this tick mark.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many equal parts are between 0 and 1.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts of the number line with equal parts

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] The number line is divided into 8 equal parts. [event:A_compare_shaded] The highlighted tick is the first mark after zero.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the shaded tick on a number line to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to find this. [event:A_arrow] When we count from zero to the highlighted tick, we move one-eighth of the way along the number line. Since the line is divided into 8 equal parts, the first tick represents [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. That's how we identify the first [vocab]position[/vocab] on a number line divided into eighths.

on_correct.dialogue: Correct. The first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] on a [vocab]number line[/vocab] divided into eighths is one-eighth.
